mainClaim: Four-day workweeks maintain or increase productivity while dramatically improving employee wellbeing
evidence: Largest trial ever - 61 UK companies, 2,900 employees, 6 months - showed revenue increased 35% on average, staff turnover dropped 57%, and 92% of companies continued the policy after trial ended. Iceland's trials with 2,500 workers showed productivity remained constant or improved in majority of workplaces. Employee stress and burnout decreased 71%, work-life balance ratings increased by 45 points.
supportingPoints: Reduced hours force efficiency gains and elimination of time-wasting meetings
Three-day weekends allow full mental recovery and prevent burnout
Attraction/retention tool in competitive talent markets
Environmental impact: reduced commuting and office energy use
limitations: Results vary by industry - difficult for 24/7 operations or customer-facing roles. May not work for hourly workers paid for time. Requires significant organizational restructuring. Long-term effects beyond 12 months less studied.
